# Translation & Shifting

c4n y0u c4p7u23 7h3 f149?
-> can you capture the flag

01101100 01100101 01110100 01110011 00100000 01110100 01110010 01111001 00100000 01110011 01101111 01101101 01100101 00100000 01100010 01101001 01101110 01100001 01110010 01111001 00100000 01101111 01110101 01110100 00100001
- From Binary translation
-> lets try some binary out!

MJQXGZJTGIQGS4ZAON2XAZLSEBRW63LNN5XCA2LOEBBVIRRHOM======
- '======' = Base encoding
- Base32 translation
-> base32 is super common in CTF's

RWFjaCBCYXNlNjQgZGlnaXQgcmVwcmVzZW50cyBleGFjdGx5IDYgYml0cyBvZiBkYXRhLg==
- '==' = Base encoding
- Base64 translation
-> Each Base64 digit represents exactly 6 bits of data.

68 65 78 61 64 65 63 69 6d 61 6c 20 6f 72 20 62 61 73 65 31 36 3f
- hex translation
-> hexadecimal or base16?

Ebgngr zr 13 cynprf!
- ROT13 translation
-> Rotate me 13 places!

*@F DA:? >6 C:89E C@F?5 323J C:89E C@F?5 Wcf E:>6DX
- Special characters & all upper case letter = ROT47
- rot47 translation
-> You spin me right round baby right round (47 times)

- . .-.. . -.-. --- -- -- ..- -. .. -.-. .- - .. --- -.

. -. -.-. --- -.. .. -. --.
- Morse code translation
-> TELECOMMUNICATION  ENCODING

85 110 112 97 99 107 32 116 104 105 115 32 66 67 68
- Decimal translation
-> Unpack this BCD


- '=' = Base encoding
- base64 translation
- then morse code translation
- then binary translation
- then decimal translation
- then rot47 translation
-> Let's make this a bit trickier...

# Spectrograms
- Question: 
A spectrogram is a visual representation of the spectrum of frequencies of a signal as it varies with time. When applied to an audio signal, spectrograms are sometimes called sonographs, voiceprints, or voicegrams. When the data is represented in a 3D plot they may be called waterfalls. 

We are supplied with an audio file, we need to find the flag.
- Answer:
